intro: Ophiocaulon poggei, commonly known as the Florida rocknettle, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States, particularly Florida. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems, lance-shaped leaves, and showy yellow flowers that bloom in late spring. It typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils in open areas such as scrub and sandhill habitats. Ophiocaulon poggei is considered a rare and endangered species, highlighting the importance of conservation efforts in its native range.
